title: The Diseases of Modern Life: Nineteenth-Century Perspectives
descriptions:
This grant proposal, titled "The Diseases of Modern Life: Nineteenth-Century Perspectives," aims to delve into the stress, overload, and disorders associated with modernity in the nineteenth century, as depicted in literature, science, and medicine. Utilizing Benjamin Ward Richardson's Diseases of Modern Life (1876) as a framework, this project will explore a broad spectrum of focus areas, including diseases from worry and mental strain, lifestyle diseases such as alcohol and narcotics abuse, environmental pollution diseases, diseases of finance and speculation, diseases in specific professions, middle-class alcohol and drug addiction, health-related travel, education and classroom over-pressure, development of phobias and nervous disorders, and the imaginative construction of utopias and dystopias in health and disease contexts.

Title: The Diseases of Modern Life: Nineteenth-Century Perspectives

The primary objectives of this project are: (1) to track the circulation of ideas across literature, science, and medicine; (2) to explore connections between physiological, psychological, and social health or disease; and (3) to offer new ways of contextualizing modernity's problems. The methodologies employed include a holistic and integrative Victorian vision and cross-disciplinary scholarship.

The expected outcomes of this research include breaking new ground in scholarship and achieving breakthroughs in the compartmentalization of psychiatric, environmental, or literary history. This project will provide fresh insights into the interconnectedness of health, wellbeing, and societal issues in the nineteenth century, thereby contributing significantly to our understanding of modernity's challenges and their historical context.
